Award.AwardTitle: National Institute of Statistical Sciences Writing Workshop for Junior Researchers
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides partial support for the National Institute of Statistical Sciences (NISS) to conduct A NISS Writing Workshop for Junior Researchers at the annual Joint Statistical Meetings (JSM), August 2-4, 2020, in Philadelphia, PA, and the 2021 workshop August 8-10, 2021 in Seattle, WA. The writing workshop provides individual hands-on guidance and mentoring for 25 junior researchers in statistics, biostatistics, and data science on how to write journal articles and research funding proposals. Junior researchers apply to the workshop by May 15 with a writing sample and are notified of acceptance no later than June 15 after pairing applicants with mentors and senior editors.<br/><br/><br/>The ability to write well is a critical but often short-changed component of the education of statisticians and data scientists. The inability to write well can hinder not only publication of a researcher's results but also grant proposals. From 2007 to 2016, 2018, and 2019, NISS organized technical writing workshops for junior researchers in statistics, biostatistics and data science. The 2020 and 2021 NISS writing workshops will consist of two parts. The Sunday tutorial is an all-day session that covers scientific writing, as well as how to organize a paper. The workshop will cover ethical issues, writing grant proposals, strategies for journal choice, effective use of graphics, and understanding and responding to reviewers' comments. At the end of this session, participants will meet with their mentor who will have analyzed a paper the participant submitted prior to JSM. The Tuesday session focuses on specific issues for improving a manuscript, especially useful for participants whose native language is not English. It will include the writing process and details of grammar, sentence structure, and word choice. A panel of successful senior researchers whose native language is not English will discuss their experiences with technical writing in English and its importance to their success. Previous workshops have been very successful with many workshop participants going on to become associate editors or co-editors of major statistical journals. Individuals from among the 109 graduates from 2007 to 2011, the first five years, have held at least 23 associate editorships and one co-editorship. Information and registration instructions for the upcoming writing workshop are provided at:https://www.niss.org/events/2020-niss-writing-workshop-junior-researchers-jsm<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NISS hosted Writing Workshop is held annually in conjunction with the Joint Statistical Meetings (JSM) and consists of two sessions plus a final meeting with the mentor. The first day covers scientific writing, how to organize a paper, ethical issues, writing grant proposals, how to select a journal, and understanding and responding to reviewers’ comments. Each participant also meets with their mentor who critiqued a paper the participant submitted prior to the workshop. The second day focuses on specific issues encountered in the writing process, details of grammar, sentence structure, and word choice - especially helpful for participants whose native language is not English. The day ends with a panel of senior researchers who share about their experiences with technical writing in English.  This report covers both the August 2020 and August 2021 writing workshops.

Because the 2021 JSM were transitioned to a virtual meeting due to the continuing COVID-19 pandemic, the writing workshop was again held virtually via Zoom over two days on Friday, 8/6/2021, and Friday, 8/13/2021. The virtual program covered all the planned activities, with 29 attendees participating remotely in 2021, and 26 in 2020.

One important aspect of the NISS writing workshop is the one-on-one meeting with the mentors assigned to each of the participants. In-person, this occurs during the lunch period or after the first day's presentations. In the virtual format in 2021, as in 2020, we used breakout rooms in Zoom assigning each of the mentors a breakout room to meet individually with their mentees to discuss their writing samples.

A significant unexpected result of the 2020 and 2021 Writing Workshop was the advantages we experienced since the workshop was forced to be virtual rather than sandwiched between sessions at JSM. In addition to uninterrupted periods without distraction, the virtual format allowed all attendees to participate without the previous years’ issues of travel disruptions and visa problems. All applicants who were accepted to the workshop could attend without the anticipated travel and housing expenses included in our grant application. Another valuable aspect of the annual NISS writing workshop is the opportunity for new researchers to interact on a personal level with highly successful mentors and leaders in the field. We found the virtual format allowed this interaction to be nearly as successful as the in-person format.  

The success of these annual writing workshops depends to a large extent on the efforts and experience of the speakers and mentors which included: Jim Albert (Bowling Green State University); Naomi Altman (Pennsylvania State University); David Banks (Duke University); Emma Benn (Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai); Keith Crank (NSF, retired); Susan Ellenberg (University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine); Cheryl Eavey (NSF); Xuming He (University of Michigan); Tim Hesterberg (Google Inc); Dave Hunter (Pennsylvania State University); Peter Imrey (Cleveland Clinic); Nicholas Jewell (University of California, Berkeley and London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine); Jiming Jiang (University of California, Davis); Karen Kafadar (University of Virginia; Editor-in-Chief of The Annals of Applied Statistics); Eric Laber (Duke University);Nicole Lazar (Pennsylvania State University); Regina Nuzzo (Gallaudet University); Tyler McCormick (University of Washington); Karen Messer (UC San Diego School of Medicine); Edsel Pena (University of South Carolina); Don Richards (Pennsylvania State University); David Rocke (University of California, Davis); James L Rosenberger (Pennsylvania State University); Ali Shojaie (University of Washington); Judy Wang(George Washington University); Leland Wilkinson (H2O.ai and University of Illinois at Chicago); Lingzhou Xue (Pennsylvania State University).

The impact of these writing workshops is seen by the many participants in the past who have become leaders in the field and active researchers, journal reviewers, associate editors, and editors of statistical journals. Participants have expressed high satisfaction with the opportunity to meet with the mentors, both for their input into the writing process, and to build a network of colleagues who are leaders in the field of statistics.

Good writing by statisticians has a beneficial impact on science due to the importance of statistics in conveying the validity and uncertainty of scientific outcomes. Improving the ability to write clearly improves statistical journals and the myriad of other disciplines with whom statisticians collaborate.

The 55 participants in the two years covered by this grant are all in their first six years post Ph.D., thus the impact of this workshop continues through their mentoring of students over their entire professional careers. Good writing skills and clear communication have a positive impact on industry, government, academic, and professional statisticians.
